awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Ferrates(FeVI, FeV, and FeIV) Oxidation for Mitigation of Pharmaceutical Micropollutants in Source-Separated Urine: Underlying Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Although human urine accounts for only 1% of domestic wastewater, it contributes 80% of nitrogen (N), 50% of phosphorus (P), and 60% of pharmaceuticals. While diverting urine to recover N and P has been proposed as an efficient alternative to conventional wastewater treatment, removing pharmaceuticals would also be highly beneficial. Effective destruction of pharmaceuticals in diverted urine would greatly minimize the energy costs and increase efficiency of removal compared to conventional wastewater treatment. Urine is a particularly challenging matrix for the removal of pharmaceuticals. However, recent work shows that iron (ferrate) containing advanced oxidation technology (AOT) holds great promise as a treatment alternative. The proposed research is to develop ferrate-based treatment for pharmaceutical removal from urine. The project is transformative in that it represents a fundamental re-thinking of conventional treatment systems for combined pharmaceutical removal and wastewater management. The proposed technology will complement research efforts on N and P recovery in diverted urine in a holistic manner to protect public and ecosystem health, and enhance the water security of the Nation. 

The goal of this study is to develop ferrate (FeVI, FeV and FeIV)-based AOT for destruction of pharmaceuticals and their metabolites in source-separated urine. The focus of the proposed research is on elucidating the underlying oxidation mechanisms and optimizing treatment efficiency. To achieve this goal, the specific research objectives are to: (i) investigate the degradation of selected pharmaceuticals and metabolites in real and synthetic urines; (ii) characterize the reaction mechanisms of ferrates with pharmaceuticals, pharmaceutical metabolites and common urine components; (iii) identify reactive oxidation products of pharmaceuticals and urine components with ferrates; (iv) develop kinetic models to predict decay of FeVI and degradation of pharmaceuticals by FeVI in urine related matrices; (v) validate the research results obtained from synthetic urine matrices with those in real urine matrices; and (vi) evaluate the toxicity of oxidized products of pharmaceuticals by ferrates. A range of educational activities related to this project will also be conducted. They include teaching and recruiting minority students to participate in research though partnerships with minority institutions in Texas and a minority-student summer research program at Georgia Tech, teaching K-12 STEM teachers in science fair activities, develop teaching modules for undergraduate and graduate courses based on the proposed research, and broadly disseminate research results via publications, at national/international meetings, and at venues by the new interdisciplinary program at Texas A&M.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. population spend hundreds of billion dollars every year on medication.  A large portion of the pharmaceuticals are excreted through urine and feces and end up in the wastewater.  Unfortunately, most current wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) are not able to effectively remove the pharmaceuticals and discharge of these compounds endangers the aquatic ecosystem and fosters drug resistance. There is a growing trend of antibiotic resistance genes and bacteria which is recognized by the World Health Organization (WHO) as one of the biggest public health crises of the century.  This study was performed using fundamental tools to circumvent this problem by eliminating the pharmaceuticals from the source (i.e., urine), which allows effective treatment at high pharmaceutical concentrations and in small wastewater volumes. The treated urine not only leads to clean water but also resource of nutrients (P and N) recovery for fertilizers.

Iron in +6 oxidation state (commonly called ferrate(VI)) is an electron-deficient molecule (or oxidant) and can react efficiently with pharmaceuticals in water. Ferrate(VI) also compares favorably with other oxidants due to its much better resistance to water matrix interferences. Importantly, our research found that the inherent constituents of urine such as bicarbonate, ammonia, and creatinine increased the oxidation rates of the pharmaceuticals by ferrate(VI). Increased oxidation rates led to increase in the removal efficiency.  In describing the interesting findings, we determined through experimental and theoretical strategies for the first time that the activation of ferrate(VI) generates highly reactive intermediate high-valent species, ferrate(V) and ferrate(IV), to increase the oxidation rate of pharmaceuticals in water.  Significantly, the concentrations of urine constituents (or the molar ratio of ferrate to constituent) determined the magnitude of the increase in oxidation rates of different pharmaceuticals.  Additionally, the structures (or moieties) of the pharmaceutical molecules also influenced the enhanced oxidation rates. The elucidation of mechanism through kinetic modeling allowed us to estimate the reaction rate constants of ferrate(V) and ferrate(IV) with pharmaceuticals for the first time.  These values are important to optimize the reaction conditions to remove pharmaceuticals by ferrate(VI) efficiently.

In another part of the research, we examine the effect of cations, especially iron(III), on the oxidation of pharmaceuticals by ferrate(VI).  Our aim was how the Fe(III), which is regularly applied as a coagulant in water treatment, could affect the removal of the pharmaceuticals in water.  An addition of Fe(III) to ferrate(VI) enhanced the oxidation of pharmaceuticals and pollutants compared to the oxidation solely by ferrate(VI). The addition of Fe(III) to ferrate(VI) could remove the pollutant (i.e., diatrizoic acid (DTA)) from real river and lake waters.  In delineating the mechanism, we learned that ferrate(IV) was selectively generated in the ferrate(VI)-iron(III) interaction to increase the oxidation efficiency in pollutant degradation.   

Finally, we also explored the use of commonly available carbon materials like graphite oxide (GO), reduced graphitie oxide (rGO), hydrochar, graphite, and fullerene) on the oxidation of pollutants by ferrate(VI). Among the various materials, GO and hydrochar had the enhanced oxidation of micropollutants by ferrate(VI) under slightly alkaline medium, commonly encountered in urine samples.  The surface functionality of the materials controlled their effect on pollutant oxidation by ferrate(VI), which indirectly control the generation of ferrate(V)/ferrate(IV) to cause the accelerated removal of pollutants. This research provided additional tool to remove efficiently the pharmaceuticals in urine samples by ferrate(VI).

During this project, we have also conducted many outreach and educational activities, which included hands-on demonstration at the Atlanta Science Festival, training of graduate students to become next generation scientists/engineers, involving undergraduates in research to learn research skills, and familiarizing high school students to ferrate technology. Activities in summer institute of the Texas A&M were conducted to convey the concept of ferrate chemistry and water/wastewater treatment processes.  The summer institute had high school teachers from across Texas to get training in implementing innovative, classroom-ready, STEM-based educational materials. Investigators of the project traveled widely to disseminate the results nationally through conferences and seminars. Infrastructure of the PI laboratory was improved by adding the attachment to the fast kinetics instrument.
